segments.Text: Welcome to the annual Def-Con Convention.
This meeting was held an exciting Las Vegas Nevada from July night through the 11th, 1999.
This is video tape number 45.
Follow-up on Micropower Radio.
This is the Micro Power Radio talk.
This is the Dersion 2.0.
I'm going to kind of cover.
a little bit of some of the things I covered last year, plus some changes that have occurred
legally put my Mets hat on to keep my hair out of my eyes, as well as try to go over
some technical details that I kind of glossed over last year.
First of all, introduce myself, I'm Professor Fidelbaum.
I am the individual that started the Desert Crossing Radio broadcasts five years ago
with the Southern California Caravan.
I also operated my own micropower radio station in Los Angeles area called the Voice of Mercury for a number of months or years.
Probably closer to eight years now.
I have since moved.
I'm no longer in Southern California, so I'm not necessarily involved with the caravan anymore.
I'm in a new town, causing new problems on new frequencies.
Basically, what I hope to cover is a little bit of some of the changes that have occurred in the last year regarding micropower radio.
I'm going to talk a little bit more about antenna construction.
I'm going to discuss a little bit about building a pirate station, kind of recover some of the stuff that I covered last year.
First of all, some changes.
First of all, right now, currently before the Federal Communications Commission is a proposal to provide for legal micropower radio.
On January 28, the FCC was proposed to license new 1,000 watt and 100 watt low power FM stations.
and has also seeking comments to establish a third class for power levels from 1 to 10 watts.
Of course, the National Association of Broadcasters isn't real happy about this.
They would much rather have one or two companies owning stations and markets rather than hundreds of companies,
as is the case like in the town where I live, where there are 16 FM stations owned by three companies.
This, of course, reduces the quantity of people that have.
have a voice in the market, especially in urban areas like Los Angeles, where it is very
difficult to get on the year.
They have adopted a notice of proposed rulemaking, which basically means that the FCC is seriously
considering this proposal, and they are accepting comments.
Now, the original comment period expired April 12th, but has been extended now twice.
They are currently still taking comments.
until August 2nd.
I'm actually looking at the proposal here on their website.
And there is a website you can go to if you would like to see the LPFM proposal.
And let me find that here in my notes as I'm paging up here.
And I don't appear to have the actual URL in here.
But I think if you go to FCC.gov, www.sc.gov and look
for the RPFM proposal.
Basically, the low-power FM proposal that's being sent,
that's being discussed right now is not perfect.
A lot of people in the micropower radio community
would have much rather had some additional restrictions
based on ownership and things like that.
But this is better than nothing.
And should prove at least interesting for the short term.
I just want to make a couple of things known.
There's a couple of, there's a little bit of FUD going around on this.
They're not issuing licenses yet, nor are they accepting applications.
And the commission is seriously considering the fact that people that have been busted for operating micro power stations in the past will not be issued licenses.
Because they are, quote, unfit broadcasters, unquote.
That's one of the more questionable issues.
Obviously, this is some people.
think this is specifically so that Dunifer, for those of you don't know, Stephen
Donifers, like the godfather of Micropower Radio, a lot of people think there's a conspiracy
to keep him off the air, and that's why the FCC is doing that.
Anyway, like I said, they're taking citizen comments on this.
I strongly suggest that everybody who's even remotely interested in Micro Power Radio,
go to the FCC's website, find this proposal, send in your comments not only through the web,
but send them by mail.
Like every other beer online.
They're going to take web comments and put them in the circular file only counting them.
However, mail comments are going to be obviously more considered than web comments and email comments.
Um, that's the, that's the, that's the current legal status of micro power, micro power radio.
The FCC's been still shutting down stations for last year.
Uh, last year when, uh, I started talking, they had just finished, uh, taking off about 10 stations.
They're still taking them off the air.
what this means long term, I don't know, but the short of it is, is that, this kind of is the disclaimer.
If you do this, you do run the chances of getting caught, and we'll want to, of course, protect yourself accordingly.
Let's see. Getting to the thing. Oh, I might as well talk a little bit about the
Donifer-Figuero, Berkeley, Berkeley decision.
I don't have all the notes here on this, so if somebody else a little bit more, feel free to stop me.
But so basically, the free radio of Berkeley, which was kind of the parent micro-power station,
has been taken off the air pretty much for good.
They continue broadcasting sometimes on wild frequencies in the Bay Area.
This, of course, has been hampered by the fact that Donifer's physical health has deteriorated.
There are appeals pending, but the general consensus is that
With the low-power FM proposal on the table, the FCC now has much more of a case,
because before in the case, Dunifer's defense was based on the fact that you cannot apply for a license.
There isn't even a process to go through to be denied. They just will not accept them.
With this micro-power radio proposal, now the FCC's defense, now the FCC can say, well, yes, there is.
There's this notice of proposal rulemaking, and we'll be taking license applications in six months,
and why are you on the air?
So that's kind of been why a lot of people think the LPFM proposal got as far as it did.
It'll be interesting to see what happens in six months from now.
See where this proposal actually goes.
It's curious that all this is going on now right before the election.
GoFIG.
I guess MicroPyroidio isn't really an election priority.
Okay.
Kind of glanced over that.
Let's talk about actually putting a pirate radio station
on the air. The obvious things you need to put a pirate station on the air are obviously programming,
which is your mixer and all that fancy stuff, which we have plenty of up here.
You need a transmitter of some sort and you need an antenna to radiate your signal. Those are the three
basic components. Obviously, all the audio gear is very easy to obtain. A trip to your local
Radio Shack store or even a pro audio store, such as...
I can't think of the name of the place.
Sam Ash used to be the name of it, or I think they were bought it by somebody.
A place like that will get you all the gear you need, at least as far as the audio is concerned.
Transmitter's a little harder to obtain.
TP? Is Brewer still operating?
There used to be a gentleman in Florida by the name of L.D. Brewer. Brewer.
Does www.L.L.Brewer.com.
kits. And for about $200, you could purchase a Panaxis FM Exciter and a free radio
Berkeley like 60 watt kit to get to get yourself about 60 watts of power.
Obviously, we need to have a little bit of electronic skills to build this. These come as kits
almost exclusively. The electronic skills you need are nothing simpler than just knowing
how to solder. In a few cases you might.
want to pick up some skills in basic radio troubleshooting.
Anybody who has taken a technician-level ham radio class
probably has all of the technical know-how you need to do it.
Most of the technical issues that you'll have are just construction.
A lot of the kits, especially the free radio Berkeley kits,
are designed to be assembled by people who have learned how to solder as early as five minutes ago.
So it's pretty easy to actually build the transmitter.
Building an antenna is a little more complicated in the sense that it does require some actual construction skills.
We have successfully, in previous years, transmitted using an antenna very similar to this one.
This is actually a radio shack right off-the-shelf CB antenna.
These can actually be readily modified for the FM broadband.
the FM broadcast band.
It does require a little bit of a skill.
In fact, you'll probably break your first one.
We did.
Actually, we didn't. It's on the air.
It works.
Basically, what you have to do,
these are designed for a much lower frequency.
So, while that antenna is actually pretty close for
the FM broadcast band, there's a loading coil inside here
which makes the antenna electrically a lot longer.
This loading coil
needs to be removed and it can be removed by basically unbolting it and taking it apart.
You will have to take this plastic stuff off.
There's a magnet under here and there's a bolt.
Once that coil is removed, it's pretty much you're ready to go.
You need to make contact with a vehicle, stick it to,
because the vehicle acts as part of the antenna.
And this is the radiating element.
And it's that simple.
It takes an afternoon to build an antenna that way.
You do have to have metal-to-metal contact.
You do have to have metal-to-metal contact.
between the base and the antenna.
You can get away with having,
like, it doesn't have to be direct metal contact.
It can be inductive contact.
In other words, if this is sitting on,
see, this is plastic, so obviously there's not,
there's a little bit of insulation here,
but it does have to be pretty much directly on something metal
with very little in between it.
If you have a vinyl top, for example, that's too much.
Besides, the magnet probably wouldn't hold.
The real thumb on that is if the magnet holds,
there'll be inductive contact.
Because we're dealing with radio, we don't necessarily have to touch metal.
We just have to get close enough so that there's not, you know, additional inductance going on between the two.
But I've, when I built mine, I have an antenna very similar to this.
I built mine out of a different model Radio Shack antenna.
And when I did it, I found out that just taking a piece of copper foil
and sticking it on here, improve the antenna performance,
your mileage may vary because Radio Shack has changed these antennas twice in the last, like, five
years. So, about the basic design that's the same. This is pretty close. We had to
trim it a little bit, didn't we, like right around here, a little bit longer. Right about that,
shorter. Right there. That was for 104.7 megahertz. As you increase in frequency, the antenna's longer.
A little bit quick notes about antenna design. You will want to probably, like I said, pick up a little bit of knowledge about how long this needs to be,
long this needs to be. There's a mathematical formula, and I can't for the time from you to remember it, because I'm way too drunk.
Huh? It's a quarter way, it's a quarter way formula, so it's, uh, the number three.
Well, yeah, but you have to know the wavelength. You have to know the exact wavelength. You have to know the exact wavelength.
Oh, but there's, there's actually a rule of thumb specifically, and I think the number three hundred's involved.
isn't it?
Plus your age.
Huh?
Plus your age, yes.
You'll have to excuse me. I was out partying real hard last night, so
I'm not the most coherent this morning, so
that's why I'm depending on my laptop here with the notes.
I didn't make those hard to screw around with, or are they're changing
it because...
No, they're changing them because Radio Shack, over the last...
I just just, just my own internal knowledge of Radio Shack's policy.
after working there for like five years.
Radio Shack has changed vendors for their antennas a couple of times.
They're now using an entirely different Japanese or Chinese factory than the one they were using five years ago.
So the changes are just, they're purely cosmetic, and the inside the antennas are identical electrically.
They also wanted to make them look a little less cheesy, and they ended up making them looking a little more cheesy, but, you know, that's Radio Shack.
Another antenna that a lot of people have had success with, but I've never used,
Radio Shack sells a scanner antenna, which is a magnet mount antenna like this.
In fact, they have a discontinued version you can get for like two or three bucks now.
That has three, it has like two loading, loading coils on it.
It's designed to be a scanner receiving antenna and also a transmitting antenna for ham radio.
I've heard those antennas work out of the box, but have a 25 watt power limitation.
limitation.
I've never tried them.
TEP, did you ever try one?
I've never tried them.
There's no reason why they shouldn't work.
If they work on the 2-meter handband, they can probably be tuned.
Worst case scenario.
Yeah, so that's the next thing is that there's a couple of different...
These are great mobile installation.
You get on the top of your roof.
You drive to a top of the mountain.
You talk for 15 minutes or 20 or an hour and you leave.
Nobody's the wiser.
a wiser. A little more permanent installation, you're probably going to want to go
with either a straight dipole design, which there are actually instructions to build on Free Radio Berkeley site,
which I might as well give that out now since I'm looking at it. It's a www.freeradio.org.
And they have a couple of different designs.
We've used in the past a J-Pol, which is basically kind of a folded dipole style.
The only problem with the J-Pol that we've experienced is it's got a really bizarre radiation pattern.
Yeah, and it's about 14 feet tall.
So you can imagine what that looked like in the back of a Toyota pickup truck.
And there's pictures, we have the pictures.
You can also build what's called a, would you also build a Yagi antenna or even a little more simpler dipole,
for a flat dipole with maybe a director, which is a little, little, a little,
simpler Yaggy, which is just a two-element Yaggy.
Probably the best resource to do, and it's something that I suggested,
that I would suggest to anybody that's interested in Micro Power Radio,
is to go to a ham radio store and pick up a couple of books printed by the A.
A.R.
Which is the big Ham Radio Club in the United States.
One of them is called the A.O.R.R.R.
Handbook.
It's a big thick book like this big, and it's got lots of stuff you don't need,
but it also has a lot of stuff you will need.
of stuff you will need. It's got lots of formulas and tables and flots and jetson
and how to talk to Mars on 10 meters and all that kind of stuff. But it also has a lot of
antenna designs that you can look at and do the math yourself and apply those designs
to the FM broadcast band. There's also a couple of antenna designs in there that you can
reapply to the AM broadcast band, which is also a very interesting place to do business.
Another book that you might want to pick up while you're at the hand radio store is the
A.D.O.R. Antenna Handbook. Is that the right name or antenna? I think it's called the antenna
Handbook. It's got pictures of huge antennas on it. You can't miss it. It's a lot thinner
and it just talks about antennas. Nothing else. That's also a very good resource.
There's also another book while I'm talking about books. I'm kind of rambling, so anybody stopped me if I'm not
covering something you want to know about. There's also another book that is actually
co-authored by Stephen Donifer, and you can buy through the FRB called Seizing the Airwaves.
It's 13 bucks plus $3 shipping, and I have the address if anybody's interested.
Or you can go to their website, FreeRadio.org, and buy it. It's a little less technical than
some of the A.RL books that I mentioned. It's a lot more introductory. So if a lot of what I'm talking
about is kind of going over your head and you don't know what I'm talking about, it's probably a good place to
start.
Yeah, but as far as a Yagi goes, the only problem with a Yagi is a Yagi is going to be directional.
So if you live, like, on a mountain and there's like a desert behind you and a 5 million person city on one side,
that's probably a good choice because you're not going to be talking to nobody.
But for most people, they're sitting in the middle of a neighborhood.
They want to cover a pretty, you know, good circle around, you know, in an equal proportion.
A Yagi isn't always the best choice.
Because people five blocks that way will hear it, but people five blocks that way won't.
And it all depends on what your target is.
That's probably a good, just general idea to try to figure out where people you want to,
you know, you think you're going to want to hear, are, and then try to put yourself in the middle.
It makes no sense to put a techno pirate radio station in the middle of a middle class,
you know, not the middle class white suburban neighborhood.
Similarly, I don't think I'd want to put an easy listening station in the middle of downtown San Anna or Los Angeles,
so probably wouldn't get a lot of listeners.
Let's see.
Let's see if there's anything else here.
As far as transmitter designs, we've used in past years, we've used the, like I said, the Panaxas,
Exciter, plus the FLB amplifier, it's worked very well.
The design is very simple.
It's easy to build.
It takes a couple of afternoons to put the whole thing together and get it tuned up.
And, uh, let's see.
I'm trying to think if I missed anything.
I've done this so much now in the last five years.
It's like...
Oh, um, the best place is, okay, yeah, places to get technical assistance on the net.
The, uh, the, the, uh, the, the, the easiest place to get technical assistance is, um,
It was an alt.radyo.pilot, I think, is the exact news group.
There's also a mailing list, which off the top of my head, I can't remember, but if you email me,
and I'll scale out my email address at the end, I'll send you the, uh, the email list.
I think it's like micro radio at tao.c.c.a.
It's in Canada, stumbleer, so it's got like a really weird, um, really good thing.
You can also get a little bit of,
technical information, although it will take six to eight weeks from Free Radio Berkeley,
um, either through FreeRadio.org, or they have an email address on their website.
Um, you can also contact, um, us directly. Um, I'll give you my email address. It's a fetal. That's
F as and Frank, E, E, D, and David, L.E. at Radio Invasion.com. That's all one word run together.
And, uh, did you want to give out your address? Another person that is, uh, we've,
he's actually the one who's actually engineered everything.
It's, uh, is it T-Pagan or is it Technopagan?
Technopagan at MailCity.com.
And, uh, that's also a good place to go.
Um, I, I also have a page that, um, I have on my laptop. I haven't uploaded it yet.
Um, I'll go give you that web page. It's www.661.org slash the Tildo's
character, fetal, and slash, uh, micro radio.
Or you can just, if you don't forget that far,
if you just get to my website somewhere and navigate,
it's probably under, going to be end up being under, uh,
projects, micro power radio. Um, I have also a document that I wrote up
for last year's convention, which I can put up there, which is a lot more, um,
specific about a lot of the things I just kind of glossed over.
Um, in fact, that's kind of what I,
reading here. Um, and, uh, also has a specific, um, does, antenna design. It has in that
document, the J-Pole design that we've used previously. Um, that's about all I have to say, uh,
unless anybody has any questions. I'll just, uh, start there. Yeah. How do people get caught?
I mean, it's a good, yeah, that's actually a very good thing to talk about is getting caught. Um,
usually the easiest way people get caught is, is, um, usually the easiest way people get caught is, is,
uh, their neighbors can't suddenly pick up channel 5 on their TV set and, um, they get
like 10 complaints in a five block area, and it all seems to involve one channel.
It involves this really bizarre music that nobody's ever heard of before.
Um, typically who will catch you is not necessarily the FCC.
Who will typically catch you is, um, an SWL, a shortwave listener, a ham radio operator,
who happens to be a friend or relative of Joe,
down the street that can't pick up channel five.
The easiest way to avoid getting caught is to not create interference.
This is a very, this is a big issue for a number of reasons.
One of them being that the FCC's big complaint about micropower stations is that they cause
all this awful, horrible interference to, you know, they tell these doomsday scenarios
of airplanes falling out of the sky and police not being able to pull up criminal records on people
and things like that.
On free radio.org, there's a couple of designs for interference filers
that you can build to put on your transmitter so that your transmitter doesn't create spurious emissions and things like that.
It's strongly suggested that you use it.
You much, I personally, or a lot of other people in the micro power radio movement,
would rather you have a weaker signal that doesn't interfere than a powerful one that,
you know, keeps some plane from landing at John Wayne Airport,
because that'll get you taken down faster than anything.
But typically, the everybody's scenario of the Magic Station wagon driving through downtown
L.A. looking for the pirate radio station isn't typically how it works.
Typically how it works is a ham radio operator will write up a complaint letter to the FCC
stating power levels that he's observed on frequencies that he doesn't believe to be licensed.
He'll send that into his...
He'll either send it into the FCC office in Gettysburg, he'll just call his local FCC office
and fax it over or deliver it to them some other way.
And if the hand's done his homework, the FCC will do is just generate a carbon form letter that they generate.
form letter that they generate to everybody, mail it to the person in the cease and desist order.
If they're in a particularly aggressive mode, they might send a couple of agents by to knock on the door and say knock it off.
The FCC doesn't carry firearms, so they tend to be very cooperative the first time around.
They tend to only come in with firearms and lots of jack booted thugs if they've asked you to knock it off and you don't.
My advice would be is if you get two people on the door in a suit and they claim that from the FCC and the
tell you to turn your station off.
You might want to turn your station off.
That was our experience with Free Radio Bakersfield,
which is where I am now.
We basically had the FCC common and just tell us to knock it off,
and we did, and that was all we ever heard of it.
You mean like, using like repeater community, like using actually amateur communication?
What a lot of stations have done is they've invested
in free, you know, other free radio services like FRS or as citizens band,
and I've used that.
You know, broadcasting from a remote location is always an option,
but the thing is, is that if you throw your transmitter up in the mountains
and you're sitting down here at your house and you're beaming to it,
the FCC finds it, they now can just go, oh, it's on this frequency,
and then find you on that frequency.
I don't know if anybody that's had a lot of luck doing it.
had a lot of luck doing it successfully because there's all kinds of variables.
Um, by all means, if you want to try something like that,
go right ahead and report the results and maybe you can talk about it next year
and I don't have to come up here and make an idiot of myself.
The primary consequence of getting caught is that they'll come take your stuff away.
There's also a fine involved, typically a number with three or four zeros after.
or four zeros after it, uh, per day.
They tend to not use that because,
as for micro power stations, because they've had in previous years
some political nightmares with doing that for, you know,
there was an incident involving a couple of high school kids
at a high school back east that got the whole community in an uproar.
They will do that if they feel that there's an egregious violation going on.
Um, like if the content is particularly obscene or is, um,
been ongoing for quite a long time or they feel there's other issues involved.
Like, for instance, you are indeed interfering with legitimate communication,
especially public safety.
They get really upset with public safety in aircraft.
So, typically, yeah, there are serious consequences for,
especially if they knock on your door, send you a letter, and you continue.
I've heard of 8,000 to 10,000 a day fines being handed out for
it out for micro power violations.
Which is silly considering that most of these stations are less than 5 watts.
You can't be received for more than 5 miles.
But that's the political scene.
Anything else?
Yeah.
Have they forgotten something for Cincinnati and State Marrower?
Yes. They, they're, uh, specifically, um, a station in Miami
that was taken off the air in the last round of busts back in summer last year.
Uh, the station, uh, the station was taken off the air.
was particularly targeted specifically for obscenity.
And, and in fact, what, how they ended up taking the guy down was not the FCC.
It was the local sheriff's department enforcing obscenity law.
So, yeah.
Yeah, this is in Dade County.
Weird things happen in Dade County. What can I say?
Yeah.
Do you think about the Ramsey?
Okay, yeah, there are,
pre-built kits.
Yeah, there's a, there's a series of kits.
The FM-10, FM-25.
I have an FM 100 kits from a company by the name of Ramsey Electronics out of Victor New York, I believe, a Ramsey, New York. They're in New York State.
The FM 10 is a great transmitter to play with and to give to your little son and say, here, play on the FM dial, but it's not a very good broadcast transmitter.
Its frequency is unstable. It has some interference issues when you try to put an amplifier on it, and just isn't generally a good transmitter.
The chip, it's basically based on a
a common ship called the BA-1404, and that chip is the kind of thing that's used in Mr. Microphone.
So it's not a very, it's not, it's a great design for what it is, but it's not anything more than what it is.
The other two transmitters that Ramsey makes, the FM-25 and the FM-100, are a different story.
The FM-25 is a stable transmitter.
It's not a bad transmitter.
I would prefer, you know, personally, I got one, and I didn't think.
and I didn't think it was as good as the Panaxis transmitter.
It's about the same power level.
They are very easy to build.
They do provide some support.
If you're having trouble constructing it,
if you're a novice in constructing kits,
and you've never done it before, that's a good place to go.
They also sell the FM25 as an assembled kit.
So you don't have to assemble it yourself.
It's more expensive that way.
I think they want about $210 or $220 a set.
are $220 assembled.
The third transmitter that Ramsey makes is the FM 100, which they legally cannot sell in the United States.
However, if you've got a friend in Mexico or are really good at cheezing them up, you can get them to send you that transmitter.
That transmitter is actually a professional exciter.
It is designed to be used as a low-cost exciter for a commercial transmitter.
As such, it is extremely stable, it is extremely reliable, and has very good audio quality.
It does have the problem of not being legally available.
not being legally available in the United States.
If you can finagle that, it's a good transmitter.
Just require a letter for saying this to the next...
Yeah, it all...
I've had issues there.
I did get them to send it to a mail drop.
There have been times...
Ramsey constantly gets FCC people looking over their shoulder all the time.
So, if you just happen to call on a day that the local field inspector is out there
just having coffee with the owner, you might not be so lucky.
might not be so lucky.
Yeah, what he was saying for those of you who didn't hear in the back,
that a lot of times they will ship it if you just send them a letter
stating that you are going to export it.
When I tried that, they required an exporter's license,
which I was able to produce because I was actually exporting it, ironically enough,
for a friend who lives in Japan.
But, uh, go fig.
Legal to own, is not thinking...
Well, legal to own is always kind of an iffy issue.
When you're talking about communications gear in the United States,
it's kind of like owning a red box.
Depending on who you talk to and what phase of the moon it is,
it's legal to have it or it's not legal to have it
because it's an access device.
Transmitters are kind of the same way.
Technically, yes, it is legal to own a transmitter,
but you're always going to get the question asked if you will,
why do you have it if you're not using it?
It is perfectly legal to put as much power as you want into a non-radiating dummy load
and talk away to your heart's content.
Because of it,
that technically owning a transmitter is not illegal.
However, if your local field inspector just happens to be driving by
and having coffee and hears a radiation and he goes and stops by your house,
and you have an FM 100 with a 1,000-watt push-pull, you know, a transmitter there and
no dummy load, that's not going to look real good.
Yeah.
I think the FM 100 stock comes with like a 5 or 25.
I think it's kind of a kind of.
different configurations.
Do you remember?
Do you remember there being a 5 and a 25 watt configuration for the FM 100,
which is more than enough power to drive a tetra-based commercial broadcast transmitter.
Most exciters are in that power range, so that's what it's designed for.
It's also not type accepted.
The United States for purposes of a broadcast exciter.
Do you talk about the ACC laws regarding the FM higher low power?
FM?
Okay, technically there is a loophole in the AM law that does allow a certain amount of low power broadcasting.
It was entirely different than FM.
The FM rules are a really convoluted mix-up that says you can only transmit a signal
that is hearable at one bill of a meter measured at 3 meters distance,
which for all practical intents and purposes means that you bought an FM ten at radio shack or a
it flies, you put the little stock whip antenna, you're running it off a 9-volt battery,
and you can basically cover your property with it.
In AM, the rules are a little bit different, and I don't, I'm not the one to ask about this,
but there are circumstances where AM micro power broadcasting is not only legal,
it is technically encouraged by the FCC.
